Compiled by Shi Huijiao, a monk from Jiaxiang Temple in Kuaiji during the Liang Dynasty
2. Shi Dao'an, 1. Shi Fahe
Shi Dao'an, Shi Dao'an, with the surname Wei, was a person from Fuliu in Changshan.
His family had been scholars for generations, but he lost his parents at an early age and was raised by his uncle Kong.
When he was seven years old, he could recite what he read twice. The neighbors marveled at him.
When he was twelve years old, he left home to become a monk.
He had a brilliant spiritual intelligence, but his appearance was very ugly, so his teacher did not value him.
He was driven to work in the fields for three years, enduring hardship and toil without a trace of resentment. He was diligent by nature, never missing a day of vegetarian meals and precepts.
After several years, he finally asked his teacher for a sutra. The teacher gave him a scroll of the Discernment Sutra, which was about five thousand words long.
An brought the sutra to the field, and during a break, he read it. In the evening, he returned and returned the sutra to the teacher, asking for another one. The teacher said:
You haven't read yesterday's sutra yet, and now you're asking for another one?
An replied:
I've already memorized it.
Although the teacher found this strange, he still didn't believe it.
He then gave him the Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment in one fascicle, which was less than ten thousand words.
An took it away as before, and in the evening he returned it to the teacher again.
The teacher took the sutra and checked it, not missing a single word. The teacher was greatly surprised and marveled at him.
Later, he received full ordination and was allowed to travel and study.
He went to Ye and entered Zhong Temple, where he met Buddhatunga. Buddhatunga saw him and sighed in admiration, talking with him all day.
The crowd saw that his appearance did not match, and they all despised and ridiculed him. Buddhatunga said:
This person has far-reaching knowledge, he is not your equal.
Thus he took Buddhatunga as his teacher.
When Buddhatunga lectured, An always reviewed it, but the crowd was not satisfied and said:
We must wait for the next session to refute the son of Kunlun.
He then arranged for a later date to re-explain, and doubts and difficulties arose. An subdued the sharp points and resolved the disputes, with extra power to spare. People of the time said:
The lacquer monk, startling the four neighbors.
At that time, many students adhered to their own views. An then sighed and said:

Although the patriarchs are far away, their profound meaning can be sought. We should thoroughly investigate the profound and distant, and explore the subtle and profound principles, to proclaim the truth of non-arising in the latter age, and cause those who have gone astray to return to the foundation.
Thus he traveled around asking about the Way, visiting scriptures and precepts everywhere.
Later, he hid in Huazhe to avoid danger.
Zhu Faji of Taiyang and Zhi Tanjiang of Bingzhou were lecturing on the SÅ«tra on the Aggregates, Elements, and Fields. An later followed them to study.

After some time, he stayed at Feilong Mountain with his classmate Zhu Fatai. The monks Sengxian and Daohuo were already there. They were delighted to see each other and discussed the scriptures together, producing wonderful insights.
Later, An established temples and stupas in Taihang and Heng Mountains. Those who changed their clothes and followed the teachings were divided into the north of the Yellow River.
At that time, the governor of Wuyun, Lu Xin, heard that An was pure and outstanding, so he sent the monk Minjian to invite him.
An declined but could not avoid it, so he accepted the invitation and lectured. His name and reality were in accord, and the monks and laypeople admired him.
At the age of forty-five, he returned to Jizhou and stayed at Shoudu Temple. He had hundreds of disciples and always propagated the Dharma.
At that time, Shi Hu died, and the Prince of Pengcheng, Shi Zunmu, succeeded him. He sent the envoy Zhu Changpu to invite An to enter the Huayang Garden and extensively repair the rooms.
An, seeing that the end of the Shi clan was approaching and the country was about to perish, went west to Qiankou Mountain.
Until the chaos caused by Ran Min, people's minds were in disarray. An then said to his followers:
Now the disasters of drought and locusts, and bandits running rampant, gathering is not feasible, dispersing is impossible.
He then led the group back to Wangwu NÃ¼chuang Mountain.
After a while, he crossed the river to rely on Luhun Mountain, eating wood to cultivate and study.
Soon, Murong Jun besieged Luhun, so he went south to Xiangyang. When he arrived at Xienye, he said to the followers:
Now we encounter a year of disaster. If we do not rely on the ruler, it will be difficult to establish the Dharma.
Moreover, the essence of teaching and transforming should be widely spread.
They all said:
We will follow Dharma Master's teachings.
He then sent Fatai to Yangzhou, saying:
There are many gentlemen there who appreciate elegance and refinement.
Fahua entered Shu, where the mountains and waters can be used for cultivation and leisure.
Huiyuan and more than 400 other disciples crossed the river. They traveled at night and encountered thunder and rain, advancing in the lightning.
Ahead, they found a house. Inside the gate, there were two horses. Between the bridles hung a horse trough that could hold one hu. An called out, Lin Baisheng.
The host was startled and came out. Sure enough, his surname was Lin and his name was Baisheng.
Considering him a divine person, he treated him with utmost hospitality.
Later, the disciples asked how he knew his surname and name. An said:
Two pieces of wood make 'lin', and the trough can hold one hundred liters.
After arriving in Xiangyang, he again spread the Buddha's teachings.

Although the sutras had been translated a long time ago, the old translations were sometimes mistaken, causing the profound teachings to be hidden and not yet transmitted. Whenever lectures were given, they only discussed the general meaning and recited the text.

An extensively studied the scriptures, delving deeply and reaching far. His commentaries on the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ, the Sutra of the Secret Causes, and the AnÄpÄna Sutra all follow the text and compare the sentences, providing the meaning of the beginning and end. He then analyzes doubts and distinguishes the explanations, totaling twenty-two scrolls.

The preface is profound and rich, wonderfully exhausting the deep meaning. Once the categories are laid out, the text and principles are harmonized, and the meaning of the scriptures is clearly revealed, it all began with An.

From the Han, Wei, and up to the Jin dynasties, the scriptures that came were gradually more numerous, but the names of the people who transmitted the scriptures were not recorded. Later people searched for them but could not determine the era.
An then collected the titles, showing their time and people, and classified the new and old versions. He compiled a Sutra Catalog.
The basis for the various scriptures is truly due to his efforts.
Scholars from all directions vied to go and study under him.

At that time, General Huan Lang was stationed in Jiangling, and he invited An to go there temporarily. Zhu Xu, the governor of the western region, also requested An to return to Xiangyang. They formed a deep bond. Xu often sighed and said:
Master An is the ferry and bridge for studying the Way, and the furnace and anvil for purifying and refining.
An found White Horse Temple too small, so he established another temple named Tankan.
It was the residence of Zhang Yin of Qinghe.
The wealthy elders all contributed to the construction. A five-story pagoda was built, and four hundred rooms were erected.
Yang Hongzhong, the governor of Liangzhou, sent ten thousand jin of copper to be used as a dew collecting plate.
An said:
The dew collecting plate has already been completed by Master Tai. Do you think it is appropriate to use this copper to cast an image?
Hongzhong joyfully and respectfully agreed.

Then, the assembly all contributed to complete the Buddha image. The luminous sixteen-foot image was divinely beautiful and radiant. Every evening, it emitted light that penetrated the hall and illuminated the image.
Later, he personally went to Wanshan, and the entire village went to pay homage. Qian sent him back to the temple.
An, having accomplished his great vow, said:
I can die tonight.

Fu Jian sent envoys to deliver a seven-foot tall standing golden image from a foreign country, a golden seated image, a maá¹‡i pearl Maitreya image, a golden-threaded embroidered image, and a woven image, each one zhang tall.

Whenever there were Dharma assemblies and gatherings for lecturing, he would always display the honored images, arrange banners and canopies, with the jeweled pendants shining alternately and the incense flowers blooming in profusion.
Those who ascended the steps and entered the door would all be awestruck and pay their utmost respect.
There was a foreign bronze image with an ancient and unusual design, which the assembly did not greatly revere at the time.
An said:
The shape of the image is excellent, but the shape of the topknot is not quite right.
He ordered his disciples to refine the topknot in the furnace. As a result, the light and flames shone brightly, filling the entire hall.
Looking closely at the topknot, they saw a relic, and everyone was ashamed and convinced.
An said:
Since the image is already spiritual and extraordinary, there is no need to repair it again.
And so they stopped.
Those who knew thought:
An must have known there was a relic, so he took it out to show the crowd.
At that time, Xiangyang Xi Zhichi was sharp-witted and eloquent, unrivaled in his time.
Having heard of An's lofty reputation long ago, he had already sent a letter to establish friendly relations, saying:
I have heard that the true one practices uprightness, with clarity and understanding within, and his compassionate teachings illuminate both monks and laypeople, bringing them under his protection.
Since the great teaching flowed eastward, it has been over four hundred years. Although there have been times when barbarian kings and lay Buddhists have revered it,
the ancient rivers of China have been practicing it for generations. As the way of the times changes, the customs have not yet fully understood it.
Since then, the flourishing of the Way has been unmatched. It is said that the moon of wisdom is about to rise, and the spiritual alms bowl will descend.
The Dharma Master is indeed a great model, and his teachings pervade the profound. The monks here all have thoughts of longing.
If the auspicious clouds move east and the mani jewel shines again, stepping once on the seat of the seven treasures, temporarily manifesting the lamp of wisdom.
Raining the sweet dew on the fertile grass, planting the sandalwood on the riverbank.
Then the teachings of the Tathagata will be revered again today;
The profound waves will overflow and sway again in the present age.
There are many texts that are not fully recorded.
When he heard that An had arrived, he immediately went to pay respects.
After sitting down, he said:
I, Xi Zuochi of the four seas.
An said:
I, Shi Da'an of Mount Mi.
At that time, people considered it a famous response.

Later, Xi Zuochi sent ten pears as a gift. Just as the assembly was having a meal, he personally cut them up and distributed them, with the pears completely distributed to everyone without any omissions.
Qixia of Gao Ping sent a messenger to give a thousand hu of rice, with a letter on multiple sheets of paper, deeply expressing sincerity.
An replied in a letter:
When I give away the rice, I feel even more troubled by the need for it.
Xi Zhichi wrote a letter to Xie An, saying:
When I came here, I saw Shi Daoyan, who is indeed far superior, an extraordinary monk. He has several hundred disciples, and they never tire of reciting and lecturing.
He has no magical skills that can amaze the ears and eyes of ordinary people;
he has no heavy authority or great influence that can regulate the differences among the group.
Yet his disciples are solemn and respectful to each other, and they are all harmonious and orderly. This is something I have never seen before.

This person's reasoning is simple and straightforward, and he is very knowledgeable. He has read almost all the books, both ancient and modern, and he is also proficient in yin-yang and mathematics. He has thoroughly mastered the subtle meanings of the Buddhist scriptures.
His ideas are similar to those of Falan and Fadao. I regret that you do not see him on the same day as me. He also often says that he wants to introduce himself to you.
The way he was valued by the wise people of the time was all like this.
For fifteen years in Fancheng, he lectured twice every year on the PaÃ±caviá¹ƒÅ›ati-sÄhasrikÄ-prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra, never failing to do so.
Emperor Xiaowu of the Jin dynasty, having heard of his reputation and admired his virtue, sent envoys to communicate with him, and issued an edict saying:

Master An's character and discernment are comprehensive, and his style and elegance are outstanding. Dwelling in the Way and instructing the secular world, his illustrious achievements are both evident.
How could it be that he only guides and saves the present, he will also refine and ferry over future generations.
His salary and provisions are the same as those of a prince, and the goods come from various places.
At that time, Fu Jian had long heard of An's name and always said:
In Xiangyang there is Shi Daoyan, who is a vessel of the Way. I just want to bring him to assist me in person.
Later, he sent Fu Pi to attack Xiangyang in the south. An and Zhu Xu were both captured by Jian. Jian said to his chief minister, Quan Yi:
I took Xiangyang with an army of 100,000, and I only obtained one and a half people.
Yi said:
Who?
Jian said:
Only Master An and half of Xi Zhe.
After arriving, he stayed at Wuzhong Temple in Chang'an, with thousands of monks, greatly promoting the Dharma.

At first, monks during the Wei and Jin dynasties took their teachers' surnames, so their surnames were different. An thought that for the sake of the great master, nothing was more honorable than Shakyamuni, so he used Shakyamuni as the surname.

Later, he obtained the Zengyi Ahan Jing, which indeed said that the four rivers enter the ocean and no longer have the name of a river, and the four surnames become monks, all called the Shakyamuni clan.
Since it corresponded with the sutra, it became the eternal standard.
An was well-versed in various books and good at writing.
In Chang'an, the sons and grandsons of the nobility who wrote poetry and fu all followed him and gained fame.
At that time, a large cauldron was found in Lanxian County, capable of holding twenty-seven hu.
There was a seal script inscription on the side that no one could read, so it was shown to An. An said:
This is ancient seal script, cast by Duke Xiang of Lu.
So it was transcribed into clerical script.

Another person brought a bronze peck measure to the market to sell. Its shape was perfectly round, with the bottom facing down as the peck, the horizontal beam leaning up as the peck, and the low side as the combination. One end of the beam was a tube, the same size as a bell, holding half a peck, with a seal inscription on the side.
Jian asked An about it, and An said:

This is what Wang Mang said came from Shun, the dragon gathering on the wuchen day in the first year of the Zhengshi era, correcting the standard, to be true, using it to regulate weights and measures, spreading it to the four directions, wanting large and small vessels to be equal, ordering the world to use it for leveling.
His extensive knowledge and erudition were like this.
Jian ordered scholars inside and outside the court who had doubts to study under An.
Therefore, people in the capital said:
If you do not study under An, your principles will not stand up to scrutiny.

At first, Shi Hu's rule was chaotic, but by this time the people and households were prosperous and the world was mostly pacified. In the east, it reached the vast ocean; in the west, it annexed Kucha; in the south, it encompassed Xiangyang; in the north, it reached the Taklamakan Desert. Only the corner of Jianye in the southeast was not yet subdued.
Whenever Shi Hu talked with his attendants, he never failed to wish to conquer the Jiangzuo region and make the Jin emperor his chancellor and Xie An his attendant.
Shi Hu's younger brother Pingyang Gong Rong, as well as court officials Shi Yue and Yuan Shao, all strongly remonstrated, but in the end they could not change his mind.
The people considered Dao An to be trusted and respected by Shi Hu, so they jointly requested:
The ruler is about to do something in the southeast. Why can't you speak a word for the sake of the people?
When Shi Hu went out to the eastern park, he ordered Dao An to ascend the palanquin and ride together with him. The chancellor Quan Yi remonstrated, saying:
I have heard that the emperor's carriage is accompanied by the attendant. Dao An has a defiled appearance. How can he be allowed to ride together?
Jian suddenly changed his expression and said:
Master An's virtue and morality are worthy of respect. I rule the world without difficulty, but the glory of the carriage and palanquin does not match his virtue.
He then ordered the chief minister to help An board the palanquin.
Soon after, he turned to An and said:
I will go on a southern tour with you to Wu and Yue, lead the six armies on an inspection tour, pass through Kuaiji to see the East Sea. Wouldn't that be enjoyable?
An replied:
Your Majesty rules the world in accordance with Heaven, and the eight states offer their wealth.
Dwelling in the central land, you control the four seas. You should focus your spirit on wuwei and be compared to Yao and Shun in prosperity.
Now you want to seek the lowest land with an army of a million.

Moreover, the southeastern region is low-lying and has a harsh climate. In the past, Shun and Yu visited and did not return, and the First Emperor of Qin visited and did not come back. From my humble perspective, it is not something my foolish heart would agree to.
The Prince of Pinyang and the Duke of Yique, both important ministers, said it was not feasible, and still they were rejected.
I, a humble person, my words must not be approved. Since I have received your generous treatment, I have therefore expressed my sincerity.
Jian said:
It is not because the land is not vast or the people are not enough to govern, but to discern the will of Heaven and clarify where the great fortune lies.
Following the times and inspecting the regions is also recorded in the classics. If it is as you say, then do emperors have no texts about inspecting the regions?
An said:

If the imperial carriage must move, you can first go to Luoyang, accumulate prestige and sharpen your troops, and send an ultimatum to the south of the Yangtze River. If they do not submit, it is not too late to attack them.

Jian did not follow this advice. He sent the Prince of Pinyang and others, a select force of 250,000, as the vanguard. Jian himself led 600,000 infantry and cavalry. When they arrived, the Jin Dynasty sent General Who Subdues the Enemy Xie Shi and Governor of Xuzhou Xie Xuan to resist them.
The front army of Fu Jian was greatly defeated west of the Eight Offices, and the Jin army chased them for more than thirty li to the north, with the dead lying side by side.
Fu Rong's horse fell and his head was severed, while Fu Jian fled alone on horseback, just as he had been advised.
Huiyuan often commented on various sutras, fearing that they were not in accordance with the principles, so he made a vow, saying:
If what I say is not in accord with the ultimate truth, I wish to see auspicious signs.
He then dreamed of an Indian monk with white hair and long eyebrows, who said to Huiyuan:
The sutras you have commented on are in perfect accord with the principles.
I am not able to enter nirvana, and will remain in the Western Regions to assist you in spreading and propagating them. You may set up meals from time to time.
Later, when the Ten Recitations Vinaya arrived, Master Huiyuan realized that the monk in his dream was Pindola.
He then set up a seat and offered food, and everything was accomplished.
Since Huiyuan was respected by all for his virtue and had studied the Tripiá¹­aka, he formulated the rules of conduct for monks and nuns, and the constitution of the Buddha-Dharma.
The rules are divided into three sections:
The first is the method of burning incense, setting up the seat, and lecturing on the sÅ«tras;
The second is the method of practicing the six periods of worship and announcing mealtimes on ordinary days;
The third is the method of confessing offenses by selecting envoys for the poá¹£adha ceremony.
Monasteries throughout the world followed these rules.
An often made vows with his disciples, such as Fayu, in front of Maitreya, wishing to be reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
Later, on the twenty-seventh day of the first month in the twenty-first year of the Jianyuan era of the Qin dynasty, a strange monk suddenly came to the monastery to spend the night.
Since the monastery rooms were already full, he was placed in the lecture hall.

At that time, the vihÄra overseer was in the hall. At night, he saw this monk coming in and out through the window gap. He immediately reported it to An. An was startled awake and bowed to inquire about his purpose in coming.
He replied:
I came here for your sake.
An said:
I am afraid my sins are too deep to be saved.ğŸ”½He replied:
You should not worry.
It is very much so. However, if you bathe the holy monk for a while, your wish will surely come true.
He fully explained the bathing method.

An asked about where he would be reborn in the future, and he then pointed with his hand to the northwest of the sky. He immediately saw the clouds open up and fully beheld the wonderful and excellent rewards of Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
That evening, dozens of people in the large assembly all saw the same thing.

Later, when An was preparing bathing supplies, he saw some unusual small children, with dozens of companions, come into the temple to play. In a short while, they went to take a bath. Indeed, they were holy responses.
On the eighth day of the second month of that year,
he suddenly told the assembly:
I will leave.
On that day, after the meal, he passed away without illness, and was buried in the Wujilei Temple in the city.
This was the tenth year of Taiyuan in the Jin dynasty.
He was seventy-two years old.
Before his death, the recluse Wang Jia went to visit An. An said:
The affairs of the world are like this, and time is running out. Shall we go together?
Jia said:
It is truly as you say. The master may go ahead. I have a small debt that has not been settled, so I cannot go with you.
When Yao Chang captured Chang'an, Jia was still in the city. Chang and Fu Deng fought for a long time. Chang then asked Jia:
Will I be able to get Deng?
He replied:ğŸ”½Roughly, yes.
Chang angrily said:
If you say 'yes,' then say 'yes.' What is the meaning of 'roughly'?
He then had him executed. This was the debt that Jia spoke of.
After Chang's death, his son Xing killed Deng.ğŸ”½Xing's courtesy name was Zilu, which was what Jia meant by roughly.
Jia's courtesy name was Zinian, and he was from Luoyang. His appearance was coarse and lowly, as if he lacked something.
He was originally humorous and fond of jokes, but he did not eat the five grains, was pure and empty, and ate only qi. People all revered and served him.

When they went to ask about good and evil, Jia would respond accordingly. His words were laughable, his appearance was like a jester, and his words seemed like cryptic records that could not be understood, but many things came true after the fact.
He first raised his disciples in the Jaumei Valley. Fu Jian sent the Grand Minister of Ceremonies to summon him, but he did not go.

When Jian was about to go south on an expedition, he sent someone to ask about the auspiciousness or inauspiciousness of the expedition. Jia did not say anything, so he rode the messenger's horse, pretended to go east for several hundred steps, then took off his boots and hat, untied and discarded his clothes, and galloped back on horseback, showing Jian the defeat at Shouchun. His foresight was like this.
On the day Yao Chang harmed Jia, someone saw him on a hill, so he sent a letter to Chang.
An's secret connection with the spiritual beings were all of this kind.
An earlier heard that Kumarajiva was in the Western Regions and wanted to discuss and analyze with him, so he often advised Fu Jian to get him.
Kumarajiva also heard from afar about An's reputation and considered him a sage in the East, always paying homage to him from afar.

When An was born, there was a piece of skin on his left arm, about an inch wide, attached to the arm, which could be pulled up and down, but the hand could not be taken out. There was also a square piece of flesh on the outside of the elbow, with a pattern on it. People at the time called him the Bodhisattva with the Seal-marked Hand.

Sixteen years after An's death, Kumarajiva arrived. Kumarajiva regretted not being able to meet him and felt boundless sorrow.ğŸ”½An was deeply fond of the scriptures and was dedicated to spreading the Dharma. He invited the Indian monks Saá¹ƒghadeva, Dharmanandi, Saá¹ƒghabhadra, and others to translate more than a hundred thousand words of various sÅ«tras.
He always discussed the sounds and characters with the Å›ramaá¹‡a Fahe, carefully examining the meaning of the texts. The various newly translated sÅ«tras thus became correct.
Sun Chuo wrote the Treatise on Renowned and Virtuous Monks and said:
Shi Dao'an is knowledgeable in many areas, has great talent, and is well-versed in sutras and principles.
He also wrote a eulogy:
There are those who are vast and all-encompassing, and people who have many talents. The profound Dao'an is uniquely capable and surpasses all.
His fame spread to the Wei River and Long River regions, and his reputation reached the Huai and Hai rivers. Although his body has turned to grass, it is as if he is still here.
There is a separate record that says:
There was another Zhu Dao'an in Hebei who was equal in fame to Shi Dao'an. It is said that Xi Zuochi wrote a letter to Zhu Dao'an.
Dao'an originally followed his teacher's surname Zhu, but later changed it to Shi.
The world sees his two surnames and thinks he is two people, which is a mistake.
Shi Fahe, a native of Yingyang,
studied with An Gong from a young age and was known for his humility.
He was good at outlining the framework of discussions and resolving doubts and misunderstandings.
Due to the chaos caused by the Shi clan, he led his disciples to enter Shu. The people of Ba and Han admired his virtue and formed groups.
Hearing that Xiangyang had fallen, he entered the pass from Shu and stayed at Yangping Temple.
Later, he held a gathering in Jinju Valley, and together with Dao'an, climbed the mountain ridge, looking far into the distance. He then sighed and said:
This mountain is lofty, and many come to enjoy the view.
Once we transform here, how will we know where we will end up?
An said:
The Dharma Master's mind is firm. Why fear the future?
If the mind of wisdom does not sprout, then this is truly lamentable.
Later, he carefully revised the new scriptures with An, examining the correct meaning of the text.
Shortly after, the King of Pseudo-Jin, Yao Xu, invited him to stay in Puzhou to lecture.
After a short while, he told his disciples:
The afflictions and sufferings in the mundane world are numerous.

He then adjusted his robes, circumambulated the Buddha, made prostrations, returned to his original seat, covered his head with his robe, and passed away peacefully. At that time, he was eighty years old.
Shi Senglang, also known as Zhu Senglang, was a person from Jingzhao.
From a young age, he traveled around to inquire about the Way. After a long time, he returned to Guanzhong and specialized in lecturing.
Once, he was going to a lecture together with several people. When they reached halfway, he suddenly told his companions:
It seems there is a thief among the robes and belongings in the temple.
As he said, they immediately returned and indeed there was a thief. Because of his warning, they were able to retrieve their belongings without loss.
Senglang always ate vegetarian food, wore coarse clothes, and was devoted to living outside of human society.
In the first year of the Huangshi era of the pseudo-Qin Fu Jian, he moved to live on Mount Tai, forming a bond with the recluse Zhang Zhong in the forest. They often enjoyed each other's company.
Later, Zhong was summoned by Fu Jian and died on the way at Huayin Mountain.
Lang then established a separate monastery in the Kunlun Mountains of Jinyu Valley, which is still a cliff northwest of Mount Tai.
The peaks and cliffs are high and dangerous, with vast water and rocks.
Lang built houses, and his craftsmanship made the most of the mountain's beauty, with dozens of rooms inside and outside.
More than a hundred people came to him upon hearing of his reputation. Lang diligently instructed them, never tiring of the labor.
Qin ruler Fu Jian admired his virtue and sent envoys to invite him, but Lang declined on the grounds of old age and illness.
From then on, he wrote letters every month, sending gifts.
Later, when Jian purged the monks, he issued a separate edict, saying:
Master Lang's precepts and virtue are as pure as ice and frost, and his disciples are refined. Kunlun Mountain is not included in the general investigation.
Later, Yao Xing of Later Qin also highly praised and respected him.

The ruler of Yan, Murong De, admired Lang's reputation and conduct, and gave him the title of King of East Qi, providing him with the tax revenue of two counties. Lang declined the title but accepted the tax revenue to fund meritorious deeds.
Emperor Xiaowu of the Jin dynasty wrote letters to him, and the Wei ruler Tuoba Gui also sent letters and gifts. He was respected by people of the time in this way.

In this valley, there were previously many tiger disasters. People always had to carry weapons and travel in groups. When Lang lived there, the ferocious beasts surrendered. People could walk in the morning or at night without obstruction. The common people sighed in admiration, saying that the goodness was boundless. Therefore, they revered him as a great person until today.
They still call Jinyu Valley Lang Gong Valley.
Whenever anyone came to see Lang, even before the day arrived, he would know in advance.
He would have his disciples prepare food and drink. It was always exactly as he had said. No one could help but admire his ability to see the future.
Later, he died in the mountains at the age of eighty-five.
At that time, there was also Zhi Sengdun of Mount Tai, originally from Jizhou. He traveled to Qionglong as a youth and lived in Jing and Yong as an adult.
He was proficient in Mahayana Buddhism and also good at Abhidharma.
He wrote the Treatise on the Origins of People and Things, which is also circulated in the world.
Zhu Fatai, Zhu Fatai, was from Dongguan.
When young, he studied with Dao'an. Although his talent and eloquence were not as good as Dao'an's, his appearance surpassed him.
When they were fleeing from danger and arrived in Xinye, Dao'an divided his disciples and ordered Fatai to go to the capital.
Before parting, he said to Dao'an:
The Dharma Master will be the model in the northwest, and you will spread the teachings in the southeast. We will look forward to each other in the rivers and lakes.
As for the lofty assembly and the pure causes, we will look forward to it in the coming years.
Thus, they parted ways, weeping as they said goodbye.
He then went down the river with more than forty disciples, including Tan Yi and Tan Er. They stopped at Yangkou due to illness.
At that time, Huan Wen was stationed in Jingzhou and sent messengers to request his presence to provide medical care and medicine. Master Dao'an also sent his disciple Huiyuan.
He went to Jing to inquire about his illness. Tarei's illness had slightly improved.

He visited Wen. Wen wanted to have a long conversation with Tarei, but first he had to deal with other guests. Before he could come forward, Tarei, whose illness had not yet subsided, was unable to sit for long. He then rode in a palanquin through the quarters and left.
He sent a message to Wen, saying:
My wind and phlegm suddenly flared up, so I couldn't speak for long. I will visit you again later.
Wen hurriedly got up and saw him off.
Tarei was eight feet tall and had an impressive appearance. His speech was profound and his words were as fragrant as orchids.
At that time, the monk Daoheng had some talent and ability. He always upheld the meaning of mindlessness and widely practiced it in Jingzhou.
Tarei said:
This is a false teaching that should be refuted.
He then gathered famous monks and had his disciple Tanyi debate against it.
Based on the sutra and reasoning, they analyzed and refuted each other.
He always relied on his verbal eloquence and refused to admit defeat. As the sun was setting, they decided to continue the debate the next morning.
Huiyuan then took his seat and posed several rounds of questions, his criticisms sharp.
Sengzheng himself felt that his reasoning was flawed, and his expression changed slightly. He tapped the table with his whisk, but did not immediately respond.
Huiyuan said:
Why not be quick like a shuttle?
Those present all laughed.
The meaning of no-mind ended here.
Sengtai then stayed at Waguan Temple in the capital. Emperor Taizong of the Jin Dynasty, Emperor Jianwen, deeply respected him and invited him to lecture on the PankajambhÄjanÄ«ya SÅ«tra.
On the day of the opening lecture, the emperor personally attended, and the kings, dukes, and officials all gathered.

Sengtai's appearance and understanding surpassed others, and his fame spread far and wide. On the day of the lecture, the black-robed monks and white-robed laypeople came to listen, forming groups of scholars and women.
And he consulted and instructed his disciples, who sat in order, with thousands of people from the three Wu prefectures carrying scriptures.

Waguan Temple was originally the tomb of Shan Wan of Henan, which was used as a pottery workshop. In the Xingning period of the Jin dynasty, the monk Huili requested to build a temple there, and there was only a hall and pagoda.
When Tai lived there, he expanded the rooms and established various projects. He also built a heavy gate to fit the terrain.
The Prince of Runan, Sima Zong, whose residence was close to the temple, encroached and dug beside the temple, causing the heavy gate to collapse, but Tai did not mind.
Sima Zong was then enlightened and personally went to repent and apologize. Tai was lying down and saw him as if no one else existed.
Wang Qia of the Imperial Guard, Wang Xun of Dongting, and Grand Mentor Xie An all revered him to the utmost.
A few days before his death, he suddenly felt unwell and said to his disciples:
I am about to leave.
He died in the 12th year of Taiyuan of the Jin dynasty, at the age of 68.
Emperor Xiaowu of the Liezong dynasty issued an edict, saying:
Master Tarei's teachings spread in the eight directions, and his kindness flowed to later generations. He suddenly passed away, and the pain pierces my heart.
I will bestow 100,000 coins, and the funeral arrangements will be provided as needed.
Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
The cool wind brushes the forest, and the sounding strings reflect the beauty.
The bright and bright Tarei, comparing virtues without shame.
Tarei's disciples Tan Yi and Tan Er were both well-versed in sutra meanings and also good at Laozi and the Book of Changes. Their elegant tastes and interests were equal to that of Hui Yuan.
When Tan Er died young, Tarei wept bitterly, saying:
The heavens have lost their return.
The commentaries and treatises written by Tarei, as well as his letters discussing the meaning of original non-existence with Xi Chao, are all circulated in the world.
Some say Tarei was Master An's disciple, but this is not so.
5 Zhu Sengxian Shi Sengxian, a person from Jizhou, was a disciple of Changshan Yuan.
He had a pure and simple nature and was upright.
When he was a novice, he met with Dao'an at an inn. At that time, Dao'an had not yet received full ordination either. They discussed their aspirations together, with lofty spirits.
When they were about to part, they said to each other:
If we both grow up, do not forget our shared journey.

After Sengxian received full ordination, he diligently practiced austerities, studied widely in the scriptures and treatises, and during the turmoil of the Shi clan, he hid on Feilong Mountain, wandering in the cliffs, finding satisfaction in meditation and wisdom.
Later, Dao'an followed him again. When they met, they were delighted. They said:
The vow we made in the past is now fulfilled. We discussed the scriptures together, and there were many new insights.
An said:
The old interpretations of the scriptures often contradict the principles.
Sengxian said:
For now, let us analyze and enjoy ourselves. How can we judge the mistakes of the predecessors?
An said:
To widely promote the principles of the teachings, it is appropriate to let them be satisfactory. The Dharma drums compete in sounding, which one is first and which one is later?
Xian then traveled south to Jinping with Tai and others, lecturing on the Way and promoting the teachings.
Later, he returned to Xiangyang and died of illness.
There was also the Å›ramaá¹‡a Daohuo, also from Jizhou, who had integrity and wisdom. He also secluded himself on Feilong Mountain.
He met with An and others, and said together:
Dwelling in peace and leaving secular life, we always want to rectify the great Dharma. How can we alone walk the mountain gate and make the Dharma wheel stop?
We should each repay the Buddha's kindness according to our abilities.
The group said:
Good.
They then each went to spread the teachings.
Later, it is unknown where they ended up.
Zhu Sengfu Zhu Sengfu was from Yeqiu.

From a young age, he upheld precepts and practices, and had a sincere and austere will. He was well-versed in various treatises and also good at sutra and Vinaya teachings. His Way shook Yiluo, and the entire capital revered and served him.
During the famine and chaos of the Western Jin, Fu hid in Huazhe together with Shi Dao'an and others, refining his studies and engaging in debates, penetrating the profound and subtle.

Later, he rested at Shangming Temple in Jingzhou, subsisting on a single vegetarian meal, performing rituals and repentance with utmost sincerity, vowing to be reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven to look up to Maitreya.
At that time, Langya Wang Qian was the governor of Jingzhou. Relying on Fu's integrity and purity, he invited him to be his precept teacher, with the entire family venerating him.
Two days before his death, he suddenly said:
I will leave tomorrow.
When he was about to pass away, a wonderful fragrance filled the room, and Sanskrit sounds were heard. Monastics and laypeople rushed to the scene, with tens of thousands coming.
On that day, in the latter part, he passed away without illness, at the age of sixty. He was buried in the temple, and the monks erected a stupa for him.
Zhu Sengfu Zhu Sengfu, unknown clan.
He studied all the sutras, especially proficient in the PaÃ±caviá¹ƒÅ›ati-sÄhasrikÄ-prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra and the Daoxing PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra.

At the end of the Western Jin Dynasty, he moved to Jiangzuo and stayed at Waguan Temple in the capital city. He extensively opened lecture sessions. The old monks in Jianye all respected and obeyed him.
At that time, a monk named Daosong in the same temple also had talent and understanding.
He wrote a letter to Dao'an, saying:
Master Fu's profound insights and brilliant ideas are beyond our reach.
At that time, the followers of different schools all said that the human spirit has a form, but it is more wonderful than myriad things.
According to their ability to speak, they argued with each other.

Fu then wrote the Treatise on the Formlessness of the Spirit, stating that having a form means having limitations, and having limitations means having an end. Since the spirit is inexhaustible, it is known to be formless.
At that time, the disputatious followers argued fiercely, but when they saw that the principles had a place to return to, they were convinced and submitted.
Later, he also wrote commentaries on the Prajnaparamita Sutra and the Daoxing Sutra.
Later, he passed away in the temple, at the age of over seventy.
Zhu Fatai wrote a letter to Dao'an, saying:
I always remember UpÄdhyÄya Fu as if it were yesterday. It has already been many years since his passing. I never failed to think of him on the days we had discussions.
I wanted to discuss his virtues with you. How could I have known that in one day he would forever be in a different world?
The depth of my pain and hatred, how can I forget it?
The principles he attained and the merit of his study, it is truly difficult to imagine.
Fatai's letter to An, which often described Fu's principles, is now lost. Its text is sad to have been submerged.
Shi Tanying, Shi Tanying, whose surname was Yao, was from Qiang, and some said he was from Jizhou.
At the age of sixteen, he left home and served An as his teacher.
When young, he was known for his Vinaya practice, and he studied the Tripiá¹­aka, and was respected by his disciples.
He traveled to Shu Commandery, and the Regional Inspector Mao Qu deeply respected him, and set up a mid-day meal for him, personally attending to him.
He saw a grain of rice in the food, first took it to eat, and Yu secretly respected and admired him, knowing that he would certainly not abandon the offerings of faith.
Later, he obtained a thousand hu of rice as a gift, which Yi received and distributed.
Yi once followed An to live in Tanxi Temple. The governor of Changsha of the Jin dynasty, Teng Han, donated his house in Jiangling to build a temple.
He informed An, seeking a monk to be the leader. An said to Yi:
The people of Jing and Chu are just starting to want to take you as their teacher and model. If not you, then who?
Yi then took his staff and traveled south, building temples, which is the present Changsha Temple.
Later, the rebel troops crossed the border and plundered the south of the Yangtze River. The entire region of Jiangling fled to Shangming to avoid the danger. Yi also built a temple there.
When the rebel troops were defeated, they returned to Jiangling and restored Changsha Temple.
With sincere heart, he prayed and finally obtained a relic, which he enshrined in a golden bottle and placed on the altar.
Yi then bowed his head and made a vow, saying:
If this is truly the remaining radiance of the vajra, I pray for the light to shine forth.
By midnight, five-colored light gradually emerged from the bottle, illuminating the entire hall.
The entire assembly marveled, none not regarding Yi as spiritually responsive.
At that time, although Fu Lan and others saw this, they also turned from falsehood to truth.
Later, he entered Junshan in Balong to cut wood, which is the Dongting Mountain mentioned in the Classic of Mountains and Seas.
There is a cave on the mountain that connects to Baoshan in Wu.

The mountain is both spiritual and strange, and people are very wary of it. Yi led people into the mountain, and on the way they encountered dozens of white snakes lying across the path, blocking their way. Yi retreated to where he was staying and, from afar, requested to perform repentance rites for the mountain spirit.
He then said to the spirit:
I am building a temple and cutting wood, I hope you will join me in making merit.
That night, he dreamed of a spiritual being who told Yi:ğŸ”½The mountain is the dwelling place of the mountain spirit, and the wood is the life of the mountain spirit.
Since the Dharma master is using it for the Three Jewels, I am especially delighted. Just don't let other people recklessly cut it down.
The next day, he went again, and the road was very clear. He then cut down the wood and floated it downstream. Among the woodcutters, there were those who privately stole some.
When they returned to the temple, the wood was all there, and the wood that the others had privately taken was all confiscated by the government.
His sincerity was like this.
Wing always lamented that the temple had been built and the monks were sufficient, but there were still few Buddha images.
The Buddha images created by King AÅ›oka were all miraculous and were scattered in various places. Why was he not moved and unable to attract them?
He then concentrated his mind and earnestly sought a sincere response.

On the eighth day of the second month in the year of Jiawu in the nineteenth year of the Taiyuan era of the Jin dynasty, a Buddha image suddenly appeared north of the city, its radiance piercing the sky. At that time, the monks of Baima Temple went to welcome it first, but they could not move it.
Yi then went to pay homage to it and said to the crowd:
This must be King AÅ›oka's image, which has descended to our Changsha Temple.
He then ordered three disciples to hold it up, and it floated up. They welcomed it back to the original temple. Monks and laypeople rushed to it, filling the roads with carriages and horses.
Later, the Kashmiri Chan Master Saá¹ƒgha Nandi came down from Shu and entered the temple to pay homage. He saw Sanskrit letters on the light above the image and said:
This is King AÅ›oka's image. When did it come here?
When people heard this, they only then realized that Yi's words were not wrong.
He died at the age of eighty-two. On the day of his death, the round light of the image suddenly disappeared, and no one knew where it went.
Monks and laypeople all considered it a spiritual response from Yi.

At that time, there was also a monk named Sengwei at Changsha Temple. His academic achievements were very prominent. He was valued by Yin Zhongkan and was especially good at the Ten Grounds Sutra, for which he wrote a commentary.
Shi Fayou, Shi Fayou, unknown person.
In his youth, he loved to study and was diligent in the classics, but he was unrestrained and arrogant, saying that there was no one else around him.
Later, he met with An Shigao and suddenly believed and submitted, so he offered his hairpin and entered the Way, serving An Shigao as his teacher.
Having received the profound teachings, his understanding was extraordinary. He humbled his original mind and cultivated humility as his virtue.
The magistrate of Yiyang, Ruan Bao, heard of him and admired him from afar. He made a good friend, wrote a letter to communicate, and gave gifts to connect with him.
Later, when Xiangyang was attacked by bandits, Fayou avoided the area and went east, staying at Changsha Temple in Jiangling, lecturing on various sutras, with over 400 students.
At that time, a monk drank alcohol and neglected burning incense in the evening. Fayou only punished him but did not expel him.
An Shigao heard about it from afar and put a thorny plant in a bamboo tube, sealed it with his own hands, and titled it to send to Fayou. When Fayou opened the seal and saw the cane, he said:
This is due to the monks drinking alcohol. I have not been diligent in instructing them, and have caused you far-reaching worry.

He then ordered the rector to strike the bell to assemble the assembly, placed the staff tube on the incense table, and after the incense was finished, he stood up and went out in front of the assembly to pay respects to the tube.
Then he fell to the ground and ordered the rector to strike him three times with the staff, placing the staff in the tube, and shed tears in self-reproach.
At that time, the monks and laypeople in the region all sighed in admiration, and many were inspired to make efforts because of this.
Later, he wrote a letter to Huiyuan, saying:

I am a humble person with little wisdom and shortcomings, and am unable to lead the assembly. Although the Venerable Master is far away in a different region, he still has far-reaching concern and worry. My faults are deep indeed.
Later, he died in Jiangling at the age of sixty.
Shi Tanhui, Shi Tanhui, was a person from Huainan.

At the age of twelve, he left home to become a monk under Dao'an. Dao'an admired his spiritual bearing and also had him study books. In two or three years, he learned both scriptures and history. At sixteen, he was allowed to shave his head.
Thereafter, he devoted himself to the Buddha's teachings, reflecting on the profound and subtle. Before he reached adulthood, he was already able to expound the Dharma.
Although his aspirations and conduct were lofty, he was respected for his humility and deference.
Later, he followed Dao'an to Xiangyang. When Fu Pi invaded the region, he went down to Jingzhou and stayed at Shangming Temple.
Whenever he turned the Dharma wheel once, black and white people would flock to him.
He always looked to understand where he came from, so he painted Dao'an's form and kept it in mind, paying homage to it.
Thus, the gentlemen and ladies of Jiangling all paid homage to the west, to the Bodhisattva of the Seal-Holding Hand.
Someone asked:
How does the Dharma master's teaching compare to the Venerable?
Hui said:
The Venerable's inner practice is deep and shallow, and it is not easy to fathom;
The external conditions he encountered had many responsive manifestations.
How can it compare to the rivers and seas?
In the 20th year of Taiyuan of the Jin dynasty, he passed away.
On the day of his death, his body had no other ailments. He had a meal with the assembly in the hall and took leave of them.
After the meal, he returned to his room and passed away on his right side. He was 73 years old.
He wrote nine chapters of the Treatise on Establishing the Foundation and twelve poems on the Six Consciousnesses, which are circulated in the world.
Shi Daoli Shi Daoli, unknown place of origin.
He left home at a young age and served An Shigao as his teacher. He was good at the Guangming Sutra.
He also considered the three mysteries of Zhuangzi and Laozi to be in accord with the Buddha's principles, and he wrote about them.
His nature was clear and tranquil, not involved in the affairs of the world.
Later, he followed An Shigao into the Guan region and hid on Fuzhou Mountain. He lived in a cave alone and did not accept offerings.
Every time he quietly contemplated and entered meditation, he would not get up for seven days. He did this many times.
Later, at the beginning of summer, he suddenly left the mountain, gathered the monks, and lectured on the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra himself.
When asked the reason, he replied:
I can only stay until autumn, just to roughly complete what I have in mind.
A few days after the end of the summer retreat, he indeed passed away without illness. People at that time considered him to be one who knew the time of death.
Shi Tanjie, also known as Huijing, had the surname Zhuo and was from Nanyang. He was the younger brother of Zhuo Qian, the magistrate of Jiyang during the Jin dynasty.
He lived in poverty but was dedicated to learning, immersing himself in the classics.

Later, he heard that Fada was lecturing on the PaÃ±caviá¹ƒÅ›ati-sÄhasrikÄ-prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra, so he borrowed a robe and listened once, and then deeply realized the Buddhist principles. He abandoned secular life and followed the Way, serving Master An as his teacher.

He had a comprehensive understanding of the Tripiá¹­aka and recited more than 500,000 words of sÅ«tras. He always bowed to the Buddha 500 times a day. He was greatly respected by the Prince of Linchuan of the Jin dynasty.

Later, he became seriously ill and always recited the name of Maitreya Buddha without stopping, his disciple Zhi Sheng attended to him and asked why he did not wish to be reborn in the Pure Land. He admonished:
I and eight others, including the abbot, have the same wish to be reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven.

Shi Fa Kuang, also known as Zhu Fa Kuang, had the surname Ge, was from Xiapi, and lived in Wuxing. He lost both parents at an early age and served his stepmother with filial piety, which was well-known.

Later, he took leave of his teacher to travel far and widely study the essentials of the sutras. He returned to stay in a stone chamber on Mount Qing in Qian.

He always considered the Lotus Sutra to be the essence of the three teachings, and the Sutra of Immeasurable Life to be the cause of the Pure Land. He often chanted these two sutras. When there were people, he lectured; when alone, he recited.

Xie An was the governor of Wuxing. He went to pay respects to Kuang, but the mountain was secluded and steep, and carriages could not pass through. So he unharnessed his carriage at Shanjiao, climbed the peak, and went on foot.
Emperor Jianwen of the Jin Dynasty sent Qu An, the prefect of Tangyi, with a letter asking about Kuang's well-being, and also consulted him about an evil star, requesting Kuang's help.
Kuang replied to the edict:

In the past, when Emperor Jing of the Song dynasty cultivated blessings, the evil stars shifted their positions. You should diligently cultivate virtue and governance to match the heavenly reprimand. I will certainly do my utmost to respond, but I am afraid that I have the will but lack the ability.
Then he fasted and repented with his disciples. After a while, the disaster disappeared.
In the Xingning era of the Jin dynasty, he traveled east to the source of the Yu River, observing the mountains and waters.

He first threw himself into the solitary pool of the Ya River, wanting to rely on the cliffs and ridges to dwell in seclusion and nurture his aspirations. Xi Chao and Xie Qingshu both settled outside the dust.
At that time, the eastern lands often encountered epidemics. Kuang had long practiced compassion and was good at divine spells.
He then traveled through the villages, saving the gravely ill. He left the town and stayed at Changyuan Temple. Many people with illnesses prayed to him and received benefits.
Some who saw ghosts said that whenever Kuang walked or stayed, there were always dozens of ghosts guarding in front and behind him.
At that time, the monk Zhu Daolin made an image of AmitÄyus Buddha, and Kuang then led those with the right conditions to build a great hall.
It is said that when cutting wood, they encountered a drought, and Kuang made a spell to make the wood reach the water.
Emperor Xiaowu of the Jin Dynasty admired his reputation and invited him to the capital, treating him with the courtesy of a teacher, and he stayed at Changgan Temple.
He died in the first year of Yuanxing, at the age of seventy-six.
Gu Kaizhi, the Attendant Gentleman for Ceremonials, wrote a eulogy and biography for him.
Zhu Daoyi, whose surname was Lu, was a person from Wu.

He left home at a young age, was upright and had learning, but concealed his traces and wisdom, and no one could know him. After staying with him for a long time, they only then realized his spiritual abilities. The brothers Wang Xun of Langya deeply respected and served him.

During the Taihe period of the Jin dynasty, he came to the capital and stayed at Waguan Temple. He studied under Master Tai for several years. His thoughts penetrated deeply, and his lectures attracted the whole city.

Tai had a disciple named Tanyi, who was also of elegant character. At that time, people called Tanyi Great One and Daoyi Little One. Their fame and virtue continued, and they were respected by the public opinion of the time. Emperor Jianwen of the Jin dynasty deeply knew and respected them.
After the emperor's death and Tai's passing, Yi returned east and stayed at Mount Hukou.
The students tried hard to keep him, but he would not stay. So they asked the Magistrate of Danyang to send Yi back to the capital. Yi replied to the order, saying:
I have heard that when the great way is practiced, the virtuous can hide and give full play to their aspirations.
When Tang and Yu were prosperous, the recluses were not deprived of their nature.
The great square is due to the outside, and reaching far away is to wait and not to tread.
The great Jin is radiant and prosperous, and its virtue covers the outside. It highly honors Buddhism and propagates it more and more widely.
Therefore, people from distant lands, not far from ten thousand miles, wearing robes and carrying staffs, fill the capital city.
They all cut off affection and desire, wash their hearts and purify the profound.
The distant period and vast world make the deep path always hidden;
The mind is focused on compassionate rescue, so wandering does not stay in one place. From east to west, only the Way is the task.
Although the myriad things are confused by its daily calculations, the knowledgeable understand its yearly achievements.

Now, if you demand that they be registered and counted as common people, I fear that wandering practitioners will despair in the sage's world, and those of light conduct will leave forever and not return, damaging the atmosphere of great clarity and distorting the master's meaning.
Moreover, guests from the wilderness have nothing to do with the imperial court;
People from the deep forests are not recorded in the prince's palace.
Fortunately, it is examined in time, and then collected.
Yi then lived in seclusion in a secluded valley, his shadow hidden in the deep valley.
At that time, there was a silk Dao You on Mount Luya, originally surnamed Feng, a person from Shanyin, who was known for his essays and letters from a young age.
He had a simple and unpretentious nature, enjoyed wandering in the mountains, and when composing poems, he had the style of the man of Chu.
He once had a lecture meeting with Dao Yi, and later wrote a letter to Yi, saying:

I have now been able to leisurely roam in the mountains and forests, indulging my mind in the books of Confucius and Laozi, composing poems whenever inspired, climbing peaks to collect herbs, and taking them to cure illnesses. The joy is beyond words.
But not being able to share this with you is my only regret.
Therefore, I have a poem:
The peaks stretch for several thousand li, with lush forests leading to the level pass.
When clouds pass, the distant mountains are obscured; when the wind arrives, the wild brambles are entangled.
The thatched huts are hidden and unseen; the crowing of roosters tells there are people.
Wandering leisurely, treading the path, everywhere one sees discarded firewood.
Only then do I know that even after a hundred generations, there are still the people of the ancient emperors.
Yi, having obtained the letter, felt a sense of relief, and went east to Yexi, where he met with Dao You and settled down in the forest.
Thereupon, he indulged in the dust-free world and amused himself with scriptures and treatises.
Soon after, the prefect of the prefecture, Langya Wang Hui, built Jiaxiang Temple to the west of the prefecture, and invited Yi to be the head of the monks due to his lofty virtue and reputation.
Yi then donated six items to the temple and had a thousand golden images made.

Since Yi had a comprehensive understanding of both Buddhism and non-Buddhism, and his discipline was pure and strict, the monks and nuns from the four directions all relied on him for guidance. At that time, people called him the Chief Reciter of the Nine Provinces.
Later, he temporarily went to Huqiu Mountain in Wu and passed away due to illness during the Long'an period of the Jin dynasty. He was buried to the south of the mountain at the age of seventy-one.
Sun Chuo wrote a eulogy for him, saying:
The eloquent words and teachings are not in vain. Only this Master Yi has more than enough.
It is like a spring garden, laden with fragrance and praise, with branches spreading lushly, and twigs and leaves dense and sparse.
Daobao, a disciple of Yi, had the surname Zhang and was also a person from Wu.
He was intelligent and accomplished from an early age, and was especially good at debates.
Zhang Pengzu and Wang Xiuyan both highly respected him, and they became close friends.
Shi Huiqian, Shi Huiqian, had the surname Huangfu and was from northern China.
He left home at a young age and upheld the precepts, with a firm will and character. He stayed at Mount Lu for more than ten years.
Whether monks or laypeople who were dedicated to the path of excellence, none did not admire his style.
When KumÄrajÄ«va newly translated various scriptures, Huiqian's aspiration was to expound and propagate the virtuous teachings.
Since Master Yuan was at the mountain, he was able to revive the profound style, so Huiqian traveled east to Wu and Yue, looking for a place to spread and transmit [the teachings].
In the beginning of the Yixi era of the Jin dynasty, he joined Jiaxiang Temple in Shanyin.
He disciplined himself to guide others, and led the assembly with his own suffering. He copied, lectured, and explained all the new sÅ«tras.
After five years, he suddenly fell ill. He lay sick for a short time and knew he would surely pass away. He then focused his thoughts on the Pure Land and earnestly prayed to AvalokiteÅ›vara.
At a neighboring nunnery in Shanyin, there was a nun named Jingyan, who had practiced the precepts for a long time. At night she dreamed of seeing AvalokiteÅ›vara entering through the western gate.
His pure radiance and wondrous appearance outshone the sun and moon. His banners, flowers, and canopies were all adorned with the seven treasures.
Seeing him, she immediately bowed and asked:
